narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Physical Chemistry Topics with some applications in Biology

In-depth view of statistical entropy and how it relates to concepts in bio
A understanding of the principles behind physical chemistry such as themo, stat mech, etc.

The course finally gave me a better understanding about concepts that I had learned in previous chemistry courses, as well the derivations for them. It was nice to have the relations back to biological concepts as well to see the overlap between the two fields.

I learned about thermodynamics from a statistical perspective, which often involved enumerating states and calculating thermodynamic parameters from statistical calculations.
I also learned how thermodynamics are applied in biology, especially relating to free-energy and the unique properties of water.
I learned to think about scientific processes in unconventioanl ways
I gained knowledge of subject matter specifically and hones problem solving skills, in general.
How to accept the fact that it doesn't matter how much I study for this class since the exams are always a surprise and I will never understand the material.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Could have been more streamlined in organization. Feedback came back late.

Professor Ganim explains the concepts very well and detailed despite the course material being very difficult, as the lecture slides are very organized and helpful, normally showing all the details of any derivation. The problem sets are very helpful with the material and are a good idea of what the exams may look like. I do think the class could have benefitted from having more practice questions or having a practice exam, and getting answer keys to problem sets sooner so that we could have studied those.

Strengths: the applications to biology definitely made the course material more tangible and relevant; Professor Ganim made himself available after every class to answer questions; we were given the opportunity to submit corrections for our exams.

Weaknesses: the textbook was very hard to understand, the problem sets were also very difficult, the exams sometimes presented new material. In general, I had a hard time understanding the concepts, and I didn't find all of the explanations given in lecture particularly clear or effective. Lectures sometimes went too fast.
Professor Ganim was very helpful in answering questions and providing feedback on how to study and learn!

There are no strengths to this class except for the fact that it has prepared me for the worst! there are a lot of weaknesses, however the biggest one is that the lectures did not prepare us for the exams at all especially the final exam. It was biology based while the professor barely mentioned any applied pchem during the course. Also the psets were pretty difficult and the class did not prepare us for that, we barely did any problems in class and even TA had trouble and she did not have the answers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Separate office hours other than right after class could have been helpful.
The exam formatting (released as an assignment between certain times) accommodated the virtual learning well.
Strengths: recorded lectures. This was huge, as I sometimes had to go over lecture material multiple times to take notes and understand the material. The open-book exams were also a huge plus.
N/A
The online method of attending lectures and office hours used was successful.

Everything could we improved. This class needs study hall. The pset problems were impossible to do alone and the exams were nothing like the pset problems. The professor barely helped and confused us even more.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everyone seems to recommend the other physical chemistry course regardless of which one one takes and I can see why. That being said, I haven't taken the other one so would not know. Don't think non-MB&B majors are taking this course.

I would definitely recommend this course if youre an MBB major or a chem major who wants to see thermodynamics in biological contexts. Professor Ganim is the heart of the course and is a wonderful professor to have, and will work with his students to make sure they understand the concepts taught. That being said, physical chemistry is notoriously difficult so if you dont need to take it, dont take it for your sanity.

I don't really know how this course compares to the alternative for MB&B majors, CHEM 332. The small class size and the availability of the professor were definite plusses in this class. However, there were no peer tutors. The material was incredibly difficult and hard to understand, although I imagine the same holds for CHEM 332. At times, this class felt disorganized and the statistical mechanical model was sometimes difficult to use due to the challenge of enumerating all possible states.  Throughout the course, but more towards the end, it was rewarding to see biological applications of the material we learned (ex. ligand binding, protein unfolding, etc.) I would recommend shopping both classes.
Yes! THis course was a phenomenal pchem course as it fitted well with MB&B majors
NO, unless you have to! :( Then my condolences!
